The highly touted and favored Mt.
Washington lacrosse team was extended to the limit last Saturday
afternoon at Homewood Field before
downing the Hopkins aggregation.
The score was 9 to 4. It was the spectacular offensive playing of Fred
Stieber, who managed to score four
goals,- one of them while lying flat
on the ground, that provided the margin of victory.
There was no score until almost
the end of the first quarter when
Stieber, wide open in the circle, received a pass from Sothoron and tallied immediately. The play during the
opening period was extremely fast
with the forcing, riding tactics of the
Jay ten especially effective.
Stieber Taffies Twice
Shortly after the opening of the
second session Stieber countered
again on his sensational shot. Then
Lorne Guild, famed second attack of
the Wolfpack, scored his only goal
of the contest, when he ran away from
the goal, suddenly turned and shot.
After brilliant saves by the Mounts'
goalie, Kaufman tallied the first of
Hopkins points on a shot from the
right side with his back toward the
net. With only a few minutes left
before the half, Stieber eluded Swindell who had slipped, and ran in to
dent the cords, making the score 4
to 1. The half'ended with this shot.
Jays Threaten
Immediately at the outset of the
third canto, the Jay stickmen began
to force their opponents all the way
and continued to do so during the remainder of the contest. Sutton accounted for the first goal of the second half when he came from behind
the goal and shot. The Blue Jays protested that he had scored from the
inside of the crease but the officials
denied it. Thereupon the losers secured two more points in quick order,
one by Kaufman on a pass from Melvin, and one by Himes, also fed by
Melvin, while a Mt. Washington defense man roosted in the penalty box.
At this point it looked as though the
Jays might rally and tie the score,
but once again Stieber managed to
score after luring Kahl from the goal
in a feint. The score at the end of the
third quarter was 6 to 3.
Hard Last Quarter
Hopkins managed to score first in
the last period when Melvin once again
passed to Himes, who tallied. The play
then became hard and rough but there
was no further score until Sothoron
shot just as the gun ending the game
was heard.

which forced him to limp about and
slowed hlin up considerably. At one
time he was forced to change his shoe.

Victory is once again on the doorstep of the Jay lacrosse team; Saturday Hopkins travels up to the big
city to meet the stick wielders of the
City College of New York. C. C. N. Y.
has already fallen before the onslaughts of Rutgers and St. John's,
losing by scores of 14 to 1 and 22 to f
respectively.
It is likely that Kelso Morrill will
use his h'rst stringers only sparingly,
and then only in attempts to bolster
the offensive work of the Jays. In fact,
it is likely that Captain Pete Swindell
will watch the game from the sidelines in order to allow his blistered
foot to heal properly.
It has long been the Hopkins policy
to strive for victory but not to humiliate an opponent needlessly, so it
is likely that the score will not be
as large as those which Rutgers and
St. John's ran up. Another factor
which must be taken into consideration in prognosticating the probable
score of the encounter is that this
game marks the resumption of a
series which has been broken off for
several years.
As the Jays catch their second wind
for the more strenuous college games
in the latter part of the schedule, experimental work on the part of the
Jay coaches is expected to prevail.
Players who have not been tested in
actual competition, as well as those
who need a bit of seasoning will get
their opportunities in Saturday's fray.
Hopkins goes into this contest with
an eye peeled toward the Rutgers and
St. John's games on the next two successive pre-Sabbath days. Rutgers,
with a nicely balanced club, and St.
John's, with Smith and Buck in the
starring roles, are likely to offer
stern opposition to the Hopkins hickory wielders.

Bad Fielding Of Hopkins Diamonders And Hard Hitting
By Home Batsmen Gives Drexel And Swarthmore Victories By Large Scores
The Hopkins nine dropped two
games on its recent trip into Pennsylvania. On Friday it lost by a 15-5
score to the Drexel Institute diamonders, while on the following day it
was nosed out by Swarthmore College in a free-hitting contest that
ended with the Jays at the short end
of a 12-8 score.
Drexel Scores First
The Drexel team wasted no time in
the scoring of runs by piling up a
3-0 lead before the Blue team could
muster enough power to score. It was
in the third inning that the Hopkins
boys came to life and pushed across
three runs to tie up the count. In the
fourth inning the Jays took the lead
by scoring one run and then adding
to their lead with another tally in
the fifth stanza.
By scoring a run in the fifth inning,
the Drexel nine started what proved
to be the downfall of the Hopkins lead
and victory. In the following frame
they scored no less than seven runs
which was brought about mainly by
the errors of the Blue Jay infield and
the temporary let-up of Pitcher Mur-

ray Scheff. Again in the eight inning the Jays displayed the same
ragged playing that brought about
the disastrous result. Weinecke
proved to be the only bright Hopkins
star by garnering three hits, one a
double, in five times at bat. Hartke,
Morgenroth, and Clisham acquired
the remainder of the Jays' hits.
Swarthmore Game
The Swarthmore contest proved to
be an exact replica of the previously
played encounter. The stage was a
different field but the Hopkins characters remained the same with the
exception of Leonard Rubinger on the
mound.
The game progressed evenly, both
teams scoring a pair of counters in
the early frames. But with the entrance of a new Swarthmore pitcher,
the Hopkins attack was throttled.
The relief twirler, who last week
pitched his team to a victory over
Pennsylvania, held Hopkins completely in check, while his teammates
pushed across a few tallies. The final
score showed Swarthmore victor by
12 to 8.

The highly touted and favored Mt.
Washington lacrosse team was extended to the limit last Saturday
afternoon at Homewood Field before
downing the Hopkins aggregation.
The score was 9 to 4. It was the spectacular offensive playing of Fred
Stieber, who managed to score four
goals,- one of them while lying flat
on the ground, that provided the margin of victory.
There was no score until almost
the end of the first quarter when
Stieber, wide open in the circle, received a pass from Sothoron and tallied immediately. The play during the
opening period was extremely fast
with the forcing, riding tactics of the
Jay ten especially effective.
Stieber Taffies Twice
Shortly after the opening of the
second session Stieber countered
again on his sensational shot. Then
Lorne Guild, famed second attack of
the Wolfpack, scored his only goal
of the contest, when he ran away from
the goal, suddenly turned and shot.
After brilliant saves by the Mounts'
goalie, Kaufman tallied the first of
Hopkins points on a shot from the
right side with his back toward the
net. With only a few minutes left
before the half, Stieber eluded Swindell who had slipped, and ran in to
dent the cords, making the score 4
to 1. The half'ended with this shot.
Jays Threaten
Immediately at the outset of the
third canto, the Jay stickmen began
to force their opponents all the way
and continued to do so during the remainder of the contest. Sutton accounted for the first goal of the second half when he came from behind
the goal and shot. The Blue Jays protested that he had scored from the
inside of the crease but the officials
denied it. Thereupon the losers secured two more points in quick order,
one by Kaufman on a pass from Melvin, and one by Himes, also fed by
Melvin, while a Mt. Washington defense man roosted in the penalty box.
At this point it looked as though the
Jays might rally and tie the score,
but once again Stieber managed to
score after luring Kahl from the goal
in a feint. The score at the end of the
third quarter was 6 to 3.
Hard Last Quarter
Hopkins managed to score first in
the last period when Melvin once again
passed to Himes, who tallied. The play
then became hard and rough but there
was no further score until Sothoron
shot just as the gun ending the game
was heard.

which forced him to limp about and
slowed hlin up considerably. At one
time he was forced to change his shoe.

Victory is once again on the doorstep of the Jay lacrosse team; Saturday Hopkins travels up to the big
city to meet the stick wielders of the
City College of New York. C. C. N. Y.
has already fallen before the onslaughts of Rutgers and St. John's,
losing by scores of 14 to 1 and 22 to f
respectively.
It is likely that Kelso Morrill will
use his h'rst stringers only sparingly,
and then only in attempts to bolster
the offensive work of the Jays. In fact,
it is likely that Captain Pete Swindell
will watch the game from the sidelines in order to allow his blistered
foot to heal properly.
It has long been the Hopkins policy
to strive for victory but not to humiliate an opponent needlessly, so it
is likely that the score will not be
as large as those which Rutgers and
St. John's ran up. Another factor
which must be taken into consideration in prognosticating the probable
score of the encounter is that this
game marks the resumption of a
series which has been broken off for
several years.
As the Jays catch their second wind
for the more strenuous college games
in the latter part of the schedule, experimental work on the part of the
Jay coaches is expected to prevail.
Players who have not been tested in
actual competition, as well as those
who need a bit of seasoning will get
their opportunities in Saturday's fray.
Hopkins goes into this contest with
an eye peeled toward the Rutgers and
St. John's games on the next two successive pre-Sabbath days. Rutgers,
with a nicely balanced club, and St.
John's, with Smith and Buck in the
starring roles, are likely to offer
stern opposition to the Hopkins hickory wielders.

Two Contests Over Weekend
Bad Fielding Of Hopkins Diamonders And Hard Hitting
By Home Batsmen Gives Drexel And Swarthmore Victories By Large Scores
The Hopkins nine dropped two
games on its recent trip into Pennsylvania. On Friday it lost by a 15-5
score to the Drexel Institute diamonders, while on the following day it
was nosed out by Swarthmore College in a free-hitting contest that
ended with the Jays at the short end
of a 12-8 score.
Drexel Scores First
The Drexel team wasted no time in
the scoring of runs by piling up a
3-0 lead before the Blue team could
muster enough power to score. It was
in the third inning that the Hopkins
boys came to life and pushed across
three runs to tie up the count. In the
fourth inning the Jays took the lead
by scoring one run and then adding
to their lead with another tally in
the fifth stanza.
By scoring a run in the fifth inning,
the Drexel nine started what proved
to be the downfall of the Hopkins lead
and victory. In the following frame
they scored no less than seven runs
which was brought about mainly by
the errors of the Blue Jay infield and
the temporary let-up of Pitcher Mur-

ray Scheff. Again in the eight inning the Jays displayed the same
ragged playing that brought about
the disastrous result. Weinecke
proved to be the only bright Hopkins
star by garnering three hits, one a
double, in five times at bat. Hartke,
Morgenroth, and Clisham acquired
